Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Error Estimation, Data Assimilation and Uncertainty Quantification for Multiphysics and Multiscale Processes in Geological Media
Award.AbstractNarration:
The application of high performance computing to model subsurface processes occurring over multiple spatial and temporal scales is a science grand challenge that has important implications to society at large. Research on this grand challenge is at the confluence of advanced mathematics, computer science, fluid and solid mechanics and applied probability and statistics. The researchers propose a fresh new perspective by investigating and formulating rigorous error estimators for the numerical schemes employed to model multiphysics, multiscale processes in subsurface media. These error estimators when coupled with advanced computational methods can significantly speed up the task of uncertainty assessment and feedback control of subsurface processes. The uncertainty quantification scheme will use a computer framework that rigorously takes into account the dynamic and complex communication and coordination patterns resulting from multiphysics, multinumerics, multiscale and multidomain couplings. In addition, this project investigates realistic physical models such as carbon sequestration in saline aquifers with real field data from the Cranfield Mississippi demonstration site.

The ultimate transformative goal is to achieve predictive and decisional simulations, in which engineers reliably predict, control, and manage human interaction with geosystems. There are numerous applications that would benefit from a better understanding and integration of porous flow and solid deformation such as surface subsidence, pore collapse, cavity generation, hydraulic fracturing, thermal fracturing, wellbore collapse, sand production and fault reactivation. Moreover, the underlying computational technology will be available to other areas of science and engineering for many other applications. Included are the solver technology, and the algorithms to be developed involving high fidelity numerical simulation of partial differential equations. In order to foster collaboration between researchers with diverse backgrounds and technical expertise, the researchers propose a unique summer research residency program. Under this program the entire team will come together for a two week period during the summer and participate in a series of short courses and seminars presented by the senior researchers on the project. Outreach to high schools is planned through the sequestration training, outreach, research & education (STORE) initiative jointly between the Bureau of Economic Geology, UT Institute of Geophysics and the Center for Petroleum and Geosystems Engineering at UT Austin.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computational simulation is critical to design subsurface processes for successful environmental and energy applications. The major goal of this project was to address key mathematical and computer science challenges that are essential for effective subsurface modeling. Specific objectives included:

1)    providing  a comprehensive framework for a posteriori error control and adaptivity for multiphase flow computations in porous media;

2)    developing a multirate iterative coupling algorithm for iteratively coupled flow and geomechanics problems and designing variations of the global inexact Newton method combined with different numerical optimization techniques for efficiently solving these problems;

3)    designing theoretically convergent flow and mechanics coupling algorithms for both poroelastic and fractured reservoirs;

4)    optimizing the solution strategy for nonlinear flow problem in the context of iterative or explicit coupling;

5)    developing an efficient method for integration of production and seismic data into reservoir models exhibiting complex connectivity using an iterative ensemble smoother;

6)    developing workflows for automatically forward modeling of complex fracture configurations, estimating an accurate fracture distribution using an Ensemble Kalman Filter, and matching production data using the developed method;

7)    developing on-node memory sharing feature with a framework to improve data IO performance for tightly coupled in-situ workflows.

There are many research accomplishments under these goals. Here is a list of some of the outcomes of the project.

(1)      We have developed a comprehensive framework for a posteriori error control and adaptivity for multiphase flows in porous media. These explicitly computable estimators provide an upper bound on the error measure. The framework is general enough and can be easily adapted to any particular numerical method. In addition, for the case of two-phase incompressible flow, there is a mathematically rigorous proof for the errors in energy norms being controlled by the given estimators. A decomposition and explicit identification of the error into spatial, temporal, linear and algebraic components has been obtained. This decomposition allows us an insight into the critical component of error leading to the loss of convergence.

(2)      A multirate formulation for the iteratively coupled flow and geomechanics problems was introduced. By exploiting the inherent differences in time scales between the geomechanics and porous media flow changes, the multirate algorithm allows for a much larger geomechanics time-step as compared to flow time-step thereby reducing the overall computational cost. A mathematically rigorous analysis for this multirate approach was presented which studies the convergence of the algorithm for both conventional and fractured reservoirs.

(3)      A robust and efficient framework for simulation and integration of geomechanical responses into reservoir models was developed. We have applied this algorithm to a real-world CO2 capture and storage project in In Salah in Algeria. Surface deformation data associated with the gas injection and production observed using interferometric synthetic­aperture radar (InSAR) was integrated to model and simulate the coupled reservoir­geomechanical responses.
